A few more thoughts. Fitness sharing is a form local competition and
this i=
dea is already explored to some (considerable?) degree in the EA
literature=
. A distinction is made between implicit and explicit
fitness sharing (perh=
aps a slightly poor choice of terminology, but
I'll let that slide for now)=
. Implicit =3D fitness sharing based on
phenotype similarity, explicit =3D =
fitness sharing based on genotype
similarity. For NEAT the genotype/phenoty=
pe distinction is moot on
account of being a direct encoding. I did however=
 encounter one paper
that looked at using a combination of implicit *and* e=
xplicit based
fitness sharing to overcome the problem of distinct genomes e=
ncoding
the same or similar phenotypes (and possibly distinct phenotypes
ha=
ving similar genotypes - e.g. if the encoding is indirect and
powerful and =
therefore small changes in the genetic space potentially
cause big changes =
in phenotype).

   "A Multi-Niching Multi-Objective Genetic Algorithm for S=
olving
Complex Multimodal Problems",
   S. L. Avila (*), L. Kr=E4henb=FChl =
(*), B. Sareni (**)
    http://hal.archives-ouvertes.fr/docs/00/39/86/60/PD=
F/OIPE2006_Avila-Sareni.pdf

I believe the scheme I outlined adds another t=
ype of similarity space
conceptually one level higher than phenotype and wh=
at I would call
/strategy/ space (very similar or perhaps the same concept =
as novelty
space). I also wonder if it's the case that this strategy space =
is the
space we are actually interested in when trying to maintain diverse
=
populations, and if so this would imply that the genotype and
phenotype spa=
ces are actually just proxies for this strategy space -
and perhaps ineffic=
ient ones at that. I'm just throwing ideas around
at this stage.

I'm tryin=
g to clarify/condense my thoughts on this subject into a
short article/pape=
r, but the way things are going it's looking like it
might take a while to =
settle on a clear idea of what it is I'm
actually trying to describe/solve,=
 and to determine if I'm just
retreading old ground in the EA literature - =
I don't think so from
what I've seen so far.

We also seem to have corrupte=
d the notion of pareto fronts in
multi-objective functions, Joel and Ken by=
 having a novelty objective
that doesn't have a good<-->bad direction to it=
 - everywhere is
equally good. And me by placign two objective functions on=
 the same
axis - again ending up with an axis with no good<-->bad direction=
.
Maybe pareto fronts are not relevant, but they seem to be in very
similar=
 territory.

Colin
